topic.title: Any Mgtow people or sites here?
topic.body: I'm curious if there are Mgtow people or sites here on Zeronet.

2_16ruLucRLto6GhT1Zb3P8JVZzC48fxd9Cc.body:
Yes, but I suggest to try bual-boot first. Linux Mint is a good one, and suitable for most of the everyday needs. I also switched my laptop to Linux, and I only kept my windows for some special stuff that does not exist for linux. You can also game on linux (here are a lot of good games https://lgdb.org/ and probably there is a way to tinker mainstream games to run on linux.) Mint has a built-in driver manager for factory-made (closed source but free) drivers. There is a software manager, and a more sophisticated package manager. Use those to install things in a reliable way. Start GUFW firewall, and get an antivirus (because why not). 

Look for open source (GNU GPL) alternatives of popular software:
MS Office : Libre Office
Photoshop: Gimp (XnView is also good for simple editing, converting)
Video editors: Openshot, and some others also have Linux versions
Firefox : the same for Linux
CD/DVD writer: very good apps built-in the distributions
audio editing: Audacity
video player: VLC

But, since it is a laptop (that might get stolen) it is worth to have full disk encryption, that is extremely tricky on dual boot from a single SSD. 

for me what I am testing now:
-Veracrypt bootloader in MBR 
-Windows 7 partition (not the full disk) encrypted by Veracrypt
-Windows 7 bootloader modified by EasyBCD to boot the Grub boot partition if I want
-/dev/sda3 : grub boot partition (1GB is necessary, I don't remember why, but I had issues with only 100 MB partition) (mount it to /boot)
-Linux installed in an encrypted partition (mounted as / )
-some empty space (for garbage collection of SSD 10% of unused space is good to have)
-do not use swap partition, if you don't need it (just put at least 8GB of RAM in the laptop). An unencrypted swap can leak personal data. 

-Also encrypt the secondary HDD via a Veracrypt file container (it is more compatible, and you don't risk formatting it accidentally due to the stupid message popup saying"disk needs to be formatted before use" , that happens when you plug an encrypted disk in Win7)
